Subject: Idea concerning image enlargement...
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=115403844
X-Yahoo-Profile: jarrowwx

From the beginning, I was concerned about one thing:  The output is a fixed 
multiplicative factor.  I didn't like that.  I suspect that deep in the 
bowels of the network is a continuous function, but how we access it renders 
it discreet.  I really wanted continuous, but figured I had to settle for 
discreet.

But this morning, I had an idea.  Tell me if you think this might work...

Instead of having an output matrix, have only a single output node, 
representing a single output pixel.  Then add four additional inputs:  The 
x,y position of the upper left corner of the region of interest, and the 
lower right corner.  The output is to represent the average of the function 
described by the rest of the network at the specified location relative to 
the input space.  0,0 represents the upper left corner of the input sample, 
and 1,1 represents the opposite corner.

I realize that it would make more sense if described visually.  I'll try...

Input:
[  ] bias
[  ][  ][  ][  ]  pixels
[  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ] x1
[  ] y1
[  ] x2
[  ] y2

Output:
[  ] output pixel value that is the average for the region x1,y1-x2,y2

Thus, the output region would be (for a 2x enlargement)
[  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][a][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ][b][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ]
[  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ][  ]

So if x1 = 0.25 and x2 = 0.375, y1=0.25 and y2=0.375, the output of the 
network should be the pixel labeled 'a'.  Whereas, if all other input is 
kept the same but x1=0.5, x2=0.625, y1=0.625, y2=0.75, then the output 
corresponds to 'b'.  If I were to input 0,0-0.25,0.25, I should get as an 
output the value of the input pixel at 0,0.  And once trained, I could get 
ANY level of enlargement by just sampling the network at progressively 
smaller intervals.

The best part is, it is more conducive to complexification.  With a number 
of input nodes, and only a single output node, it can complexify the way it 
should.

So, what do you think?  Sound plausable?  Any known reason why such an 
approach might be doomed to failure?

-- John
